trial_identification.studytitle: Effect of sodium and potassium supplementation on blood vessel function
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effect of sodium and potassium supplementation on blood vessel function in healthy adults

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Diseases of the vasculature and circulation including the lymphatic system

interventions.interventions: Arm 1) High potassium, high sodium meal (38mmol potassium; 65mmol sodium) Arm 2) Low potassium, high sodium meal (3.1mmol potassium; 65mmol sodium) Each meal is consumed within 5minutes and there is a minimum 7day washout between visits
interventions.comparator: Arm 3) low potassium, low sodium meal (3.1mmol potassium; 5.5mmol sodium)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Edonthelial function as assessed by flow mediated dilatation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity measured using Sphygmo-CorEXCEL
Augmentation index measured by pulse wave analysis using Sphygmo-CorEXCEL

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 18-70yr BMI greather than 18kg/m2 and less than 30kg/m2 SBP <90mmHg DBP<130mmHg weight stable for 6mo
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Use of antihypertensive medication, systemic steroids, folate supplementation or non-steroidal antiinflammatory drugs Metabolic disease such as liver or kidney disease Treated hypertension Previous clinical cardiovascular disease Unable to comprehend protocol

trial_design.concealment: Subjects contact researchers following advertisement, undergo telephone screening and are allocated to treatment order on arrival for first visit
trial_design.sequence: Subjects are allocated treatment order by an online random sequence number generator by a person independent of the study
trial_design.statisticalmethods: Based on power calculations from our previous study, with 80% power, p<0.05 to detect a minimum change in FMD of 1.3% absolute, 40 people were required in a cross over study.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of this study is determine the effect of sodium to potassium ratio on postprandial endothelial function in healthy subjects. We speculate that a low sodium to potassium ratio improves postprandial endothelial function compared to high sodium to potassium ratio.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: University of South Australia Human Research Ethics Committee
